topic: Analyzing Statements of Cash Flows II

questions.title: Analyzing Statements of Cash Flows II
questions.question: One appropriate method of preparing a common-size cash flow statement is to show each line item:

choices.A: of revenue and expense as a percentage of net revenue.
choices.B: on the cash flow statement as a percentage of net revenue.
choices.C: on the cash flow statement as a percentage of total cash outflows.

questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. An appropriate method to prepare a common-size cash flow statement is to show each line item on the cash flow statement as a percentage of net revenue. An alternative way to prepare a statement of cash flows is to show each item of cash inflow as a percentage of total inflows and each item of cash outflows as a percentage of total outflows.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. An appropriate method to prepare a common-size cash flow statement is to show each line item on the cash flow statement as a percentage of net revenue. An alternative way to prepare a statement of cash flows is to show each item of cash inflow as a percentage of total inflows and each item of cash outflows as a percentage of total outflows.

questions.title: Analyzing Statements of Cash Flows II
questions.question:
An analyst gathers the following information (in € thousands) about a company:

Cash flow from operating activities 120
Capital expenditures 50
Depreciation 15
Interest paid and expensed 4

If interest paid is classified as a cash flow from financing activities and the income tax rate is 25%, FCFF (in € thousands) is:

  1. 70.
  2. 73.
  3. 85.
questions.explanation: Solution Correct because, while FCFF = CFO + Int(1 – Tax rate) – FCInv, if interest paid is included in financing activities, then CFO does not have to be adjusted for Int(1 – Tax rate). Accordingly, for this company, FCFF = CFO – FCInv; or = 120 – 50 = 70. Incorrect because it assumes interest paid is classified as a cash flow from operating activities. Accordingly, FCFF = CFO + Int(1 – Tax rate) – FCInv; or = 120 + [4 × (1 – 25%)] – 50; or = 120 + 3 – 50 = 73. Incorrect because it assumes that CFO (instead of Net income) should have been adjusted for depreciation. Accordingly, FCFF = CFO + Depreciation – FCInv; or = 120 + 15 – 50 = 85. Analyzing Statements of Cash Flows II calculate and interpret free cash flow to the firm, free cash flow to equity, and performance and coverage cash flow ratios
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Correct because, while FCFF = CFO + Int(1 – Tax rate) – FCInv, if interest paid is included in financing activities, then CFO does not have to be adjusted for Int(1 – Tax rate). Accordingly, for this company, FCFF = CFO – FCInv; or = 120 – 50 = 70.

  2. Incorrect because it assumes interest paid is classified as a cash flow from operating activities. Accordingly, FCFF = CFO + Int(1 – Tax rate) – FCInv; or = 120 + [4 × (1 – 25%)] – 50; or = 120 + 3 – 50 = 73.

  3. Incorrect because it assumes that CFO (instead of Net income) should have been adjusted for depreciation. Accordingly, FCFF = CFO + Depreciation – FCInv; or = 120 + 15 – 50 = 85.

questions.title: Analyzing Statements of Cash Flows II
questions.question:
The following common-size cash flow statement is available for a company:

Cash Flow Statement for the Years Ended 31 December

Inflows Percentage of Total Inflows
2016 2015
Cash received from customers 88.1 97.4
Proceeds from disposal of property, plant, and equipment 0.3 0.3
Proceeds from issuance of bonds 11.6 2.3
Total 100.0 100.0
Outflows Percentage of Total Outflows
2016 2015
Cash paid to suppliers and employees 71.0 70.7
Payments for investments in property, plant, and equipment 10.5 10.6
Payments made for financial instruments not included under cash equivalents 2.0 0.2
Payments for investments in companies, net of cash and cash equivalents 0.1 2.9
Transactions with equity holders 8.8 9.0
Repayments of loans, borrowings, and promissory notes 7.6 6.6
Total 100.0 100.0

Compared with 2015, which of the following statements about 2016 is most accurate? The company:

  1. had a positive net operating cash flow.
  2. directed a larger portion of cash outflows to investing activities.
  3. relied more heavily on financing activities to generate cash inflows.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. As the actual total inflows and outflows are not known the relative size of the inflows and outflows from each activity cannot be compared on an absolute basis, therefore it is not possible to conclude on whether operating cash flows were positive or negative. Incorrect. Investing outflows includes payments on PP, financial instruments and investments in other companies. In 2016 this is 10.5 + 2.0 + 0.1 = 12.6 and in 2015: 10.6 + 0.2 + 2.9 = 13.7, therefore the portion of outflows spent on investing activities decreased. Correct. The cash inflows from financing activities in 2016 are 11.6% from bonds, which is greater than the 2.3% in 2015. Therefore, the company did rely more heavily on financing activities to generate cash inflows in 2016. Because the actual total inflows and outflows are not known, the relative size of the inflows and outflows from each activity cannot be compared on an absolute basis. Therefore, it is not possible to conclude whether operating cash flows were positive or negative. Investing outflows includes payments on PP, financial instruments, and investments in other companies. For 2016, this calculation is 10.5 + 2.0 + 0.1 = 12.6%, and for 2015, it is 10.6 + 0.2 + 2.9 = 13.7%. Therefore, the portion of outflows spent on investing activities decreased. Analyzing Statements of Cash Flows II analyze and interpret both reported and common-size cash flow statements
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. As the actual total inflows and outflows are not known the relative size of the inflows and outflows from each activity cannot be compared on an absolute basis, therefore it is not possible to conclude on whether operating cash flows were positive or negative.

  2. Incorrect. Investing outflows includes payments on PP, financial instruments and investments in other companies. In 2016 this is 10.5 + 2.0 + 0.1 = 12.6 and in 2015: 10.6 + 0.2 + 2.9 = 13.7, therefore the portion of outflows spent on investing activities decreased.

  3. Correct. The cash inflows from financing activities in 2016 are 11.6% from bonds, which is greater than the 2.3% in 2015. Therefore, the company did rely more heavily on financing activities to generate cash inflows in 2016. Because the actual total inflows and outflows are not known, the relative size of the inflows and outflows from each activity cannot be compared on an absolute basis. Therefore, it is not possible to conclude whether operating cash flows were positive or negative. Investing outflows includes payments on PP, financial instruments, and investments in other companies. For 2016, this calculation is 10.5 + 2.0 + 0.1 = 12.6%, and for 2015, it is 10.6 + 0.2 + 2.9 = 13.7%. Therefore, the portion of outflows spent on investing activities decreased.

questions.title: Analyzing Statements of Cash Flows II
questions.question: Which of the following is an appropriate method of computing free cash flow to the firm?

choices.A: Add operating cash flows to capital expenditures and deduct after-tax interest payments.
choices.B: Add operating cash flows to after-tax interest payments and deduct capital expenditures.
choices.C: Deduct both after-tax interest payments and capital expenditures from operating cash flows.

questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. Free cash flow to the firm can be computed as operating cash flows plus after-tax interest expense less capital expenditures.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. Free cash flow to the firm can be computed as operating cash flows plus after-tax interest expense less capital expenditures.

questions.title: Analyzing Statements of Cash Flows II
questions.question:
The following financial statement data are available for a company:
Metric $ thousands
Operating income 3,390
Net income 2,210
Operating assets 3,850
Change in cash and cash equivalents 1,010
Change in cash from operating activities 1,750
Free cash flow to the firm 2,240

The company’s cash-to-income ratio is closest to:

  1. 0.79.
  2. 0.66.
  3. 0.52.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. The calculation incorrectly uses net income in the denominator. Incorrect cash to income = Cash flow from operations/Net income = 1,750/2,210 = 0.79 Incorrect. The calculation incorrectly uses free cash flow in the numerator. Incorrect cash to income = Free cash flow to the firm/Operating income = 2,240/3,390 = 0.66 Correct. Cash to income = Cash flow from operating activities (CFO)/Operating income = (1,750/3,390) = 0.52 Analyzing Statements of Cash Flows II calculate and interpret free cash flow to the firm, free cash flow to equity, and performance and coverage cash flow ratios
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. The calculation incorrectly uses net income in the denominator.

    Incorrect cash to income = Cash flow from operations/Net income

    = 1,750/2,210

    = 0.79

  2. Incorrect. The calculation incorrectly uses free cash flow in the numerator.

    Incorrect cash to income = Free cash flow to the firm/Operating income

    = 2,240/3,390

    = 0.66

  3. Correct.

    Cash to income = Cash flow from operating activities (CFO)/Operating income

    = (1,750/3,390)

    = 0.52

questions.title: Analyzing Statements of Cash Flows II
questions.question: The first step in cash flow statement analysis should be to:

choices.C: identify the major sources and uses of cash.

questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. An overall assessment of the major sources and uses of cash should be the first step in evaluating a cash flow statement.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

C is correct. An overall assessment of the major sources and uses of cash should be the first step in evaluating a cash flow statement.

questions.title: Analyzing Statements of Cash Flows II
questions.question:
A firm reported the following financial statement items:
€ millions
Net income 2,100
Non-cash charges 400
Interest expense 300
Capital expenditures 210
Working capital expenditures 0
Net borrowing 1,600
Tax rate 40%

The free cash flow to the firm (FCFF) is closest to:

  1. €2,110.
  2. €2,470.
  3. €2,590.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. It incorrectly subtracted interest expense. Cash Flow Item Amount (€) Net income + €2,100 Non-cash charges + 400 Capital expenditure – 210 Interest Expense: Int × (1 – t ) – 180 FCFF €2,110 Correct. FCFF = NI + NCC + Int(1 – t ) – FCInv – WCInv Cash Flow Item Amount (€ millions) NI Net income 2,100 NCC Plus non-cash charges 400 Int(1 – t ) Plus interest expense (1 – tax rate) 300 (1 – 0.40) 180 FCInv Less capital expenditures (210) WCInv Less working capital expenditures 0 FCFF Free cash flow to the firm €2,470 Incorrect. It ignores the tax effect on interest expense. Cash Flow Item Amount (€) Net income 2,100 Plus Non-cash charges 400 Plus Interest expense 300 Less Capital expenditure (210) Less working capital expenditures 0 FCFF €2,590 Analyzing Statements of Cash Flows II calculate and interpret free cash flow to the firm, free cash flow to equity, and performance and coverage cash flow ratios
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. It incorrectly subtracted interest expense.

    Cash Flow Item Amount (€)
    Net income + €2,100
    Non-cash charges + 400
    Capital expenditure – 210
    Interest Expense: Int × (1 – t) – 180
    FCFF €2,110

  2. Correct.

    FCFF = NI + NCC + Int(1 – t) – FCInv – WCInv

    Cash Flow Item Amount (€ millions)
    NI Net income 2,100
    NCC Plus non-cash charges 400
    Int(1 – t) Plus interest expense (1 – tax rate) 300 (1 – 0.40) 180
    FCInv Less capital expenditures (210)
    WCInv Less working capital expenditures 0
    FCFF Free cash flow to the firm €2,470

  3. Incorrect. It ignores the tax effect on interest expense.

    Cash Flow Item Amount (€)
    Net income 2,100
    Plus Non-cash charges 400
    Plus Interest expense 300
    Less Capital expenditure (210)
    Less working capital expenditures 0
    FCFF €2,590

questions.title: Analyzing Statements of Cash Flows II
questions.question: An analyst has calculated a ratio using as the numerator the sum of operating cash flow, interest, and taxes and as the denominator the amount of interest. What is this ratio, what does it measure, and what does it indicate?

choices.A: This ratio is an interest coverage ratio, measuring a company’s ability to meet its interest obligations and indicating a company’s solvency.
choices.B: This ratio is an effective tax ratio, measuring the amount of a company’s operating cash flow used for taxes and indicating a company’s efficiency in tax management.
choices.C: This ratio is an operating profitability ratio, measuring the operating cash flow generated accounting for taxes and interest and indicating a company’s liquidity.

questions.explanation: Solution A is correct. This ratio is an interest coverage ratio, measuring a company’s ability to meet its interest obligations and indicating a company’s solvency. This coverage ratio is based on cash flow information; another common formulation of the interest coverage ratio uses EBITDA based on the income statement as the numerator.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

A is correct. This ratio is an interest coverage ratio, measuring a company’s ability to meet its interest obligations and indicating a company’s solvency. This coverage ratio is based on cash flow information; another common formulation of the interest coverage ratio uses EBITDA based on the income statement as the numerator.

Year 1

Investing and financing 0.82
Reinvestment 2.18

Compared with Year 1, the most appropriate conclusion an analyst can make about Year 2 is that the company’s ability to use operating cash flows to:

  1. acquire assets improved.
  2. pay dividends decreased.
  3. acquire assets, pay debts, and make distributions to owners decreased.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. The company’s reinvestment coverage ratio worsened.
